articles.content: Hello, I'm Shrijith Venkatramana. articles.description: Already know the basics of GitHub Copilot coding agent? Here are five ways to offload chores, tackle tech debt, and keep your workflow moving fast. The post 5 ways to integrate GitHub Copilot coding agent into your workflow appeared first on The GitHub Blog .
articles.content: If you’ve already tried GitHub Copilot coding agent , you know the basics: assign a task, let it work in the background, and review the pull request when it’s done. But what if you’re ready to move beyond the basics? We got you. In this tutorial, we’ll explore five powerful strategies to integrate the coding agent deeper into your development workflow. From tackling tech debt to validating UI changes and experimenting with branch strategies, let’s unlock Copilot&rsq

articles.description: FTC sued Ticketmaster and Live Nation for turning "blind eye" to scalpers.
articles.content: The Federal Trade Commission sued Live Nation and Ticketmaster on Thursday, alleging that the companies tacitly worked with scalpers to profit from jacking up ticket prices on the secondary market. As the FTC alleged in a press release , Ticketmaster's years of turning a blind eye to scalpers violated the FTC Act and the Better Online Ticket Sales Act, costing customers "billions in inflated prices and additional fees." articles.title: Science journalists find ChatGPT is bad at summarizing scientific papers
articles.description: LLM "tended to sacrifice accuracy for simplicity" when writing news briefs.
articles.content: Summarizing complex scientific findings for a non-expert audience is one of the most important things a science journalist does from day to day. Generating summaries of complex writing has also been frequently mentioned as one of the best use cases for large language models (despite some prominent counterexamples ). With all that in mind, the team at the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) ran an informal year-long study to determine whether ChatGPT could produce the kind
articles.author: Kyle Orland

articles.content: Valve's Steam client is pretty widely compatible with all kinds of newer and older operating systems‚Äîthat's what you do when you want as many people as possible spending their money in your store. But nothing lasts forever, and Valve does eventually end support for old software when it's time to move on. The company announced in a support note today that it would be ending Steam client support for 32-bit versions of Windows on January 1, 2026. "Existing Steam Client installations will continue t
